loans.use: to buy groceries wholesale: rice, potatoes, noodles, sugar and other products

loans.name: Mepukori Ole

texts.en:
Mepukori Ole N., aged 38, is married to Nadutari and has three children. He has been farming on his piece of land for the past ten years and earns a monthly income of 4,000 KES.

He has been a good client. He applied his third loan with KADET with which he plans to purchase farm supplies. He hopes to make a profit and use it to educate his children and expand his farming. He dreams to prosper in farming to provide a better life to his children.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Yamilet

texts.es:
la señora Yamilet C. tiene la edad de 37 años, estudio hasta el tercer años de secundaria y esta casada con el señor Alberto con el cual tiene 2 hijos los cuales asisten a la primaria, ella y su familia viven en un pueblo llamado El Jicaro que se ubica en la carretera Tierra Blanca-Joachin a 20 minutos de la vidriera.

ella nos platica que su esposo es carnicero pero el dinero que el ganaba no alcanzaba para cubrir los gastos del hogay ya que cada dia la situacion economica es mas dificil asi que decidio ayudarlo con los gastos del hogar vendiendo tacos al pastor de viernes a miercoles por las tardes, tambien nos dice que los dias viernes vende carne, el sabado vende barbacoa y el domingo consome. ella es una mujer muy emprendedora y trabajadora de un muy caracter y siempre esta alegre. ella nos dice que le gusta mucho trabajar y ayudar a su esposo y que espera en un futuro su negocio prospere y deje buenas ganancias ya que le gustaria agrandar su local y comprar mas mesas para brindarle a sus clientes un mejor servicio. Tambien desea brindarle a sus clientes el servicio de taquisas a domicilio para fiesta y reuniones familiares.

ella necesita este credito para invertirlo en la compra de variedad de chiles, tortillas, cebolla, tomates, cilantro, aceite, rabanos, pepinos, especies, leña, chayotes, zanahorias, bolsas de plastico, papas y refrescos.

ella se encuentra muy agradecida con la fundacion por el prestamo que le otorgo.
texts.en:
Yamilet C. is 37 years old and has a junior high school education.  She is married to Alberto and they have two children who attend elementary school.  She and her family live in a town called El Jicaro, locate along the Tierra Blanca-Joachin road, 20 minutes from La Vidriera.

She tells us that her husband is a butcher, but the money he earns is not enough to cover the household expenses, now that the economic situation gets more difficult every day, so she decided to help with the expenses by selling tacos al pastor Friday to Wednesday evenings.  On Fridays she also sells meat; on Saturday she sells barbacoa; and soup on Sunday.  She is an enterprising and hardworking young woman of good character who is always happy and tells us that she likes working and helping her husband very much, and who hopes that her business will prosper and bring in good earnings in the future.  She would like to expand her restaurant and buy more tables to provide better service to her customers.  She would also like to cater parties and family reunions in customer’s homes.

She needs the money from this loan to buy peppers, tortillas, onions, tomatoes, cilantro, cooking oil, radishes, cucumbers, spices, firewood, chayotes, carrots, plastic bags, potatoes, and soft drinks.  She is very grateful to the foundation for granting this loan.

loans.use: to buy ingredients

loans.name: Nancy Del Carmen

texts.es:
Nancy, tiene 3 años de vivir en soledad, en una vivienda bifamiliar con su esposo que es trabajador independiente. Ella  se dedica a la venta de mercancías por catálogos, y con el apoyo de su esposo y sus hijos apoyan el sostenimiento de su hogar, Nancy  se encuentra vinculada a varias revistas, a través de las cuales ofrece muchos artículos, como recipientes de cocina, cosméticos, ropa interior, medicina natural etc.  En su negocio posee  una vitrina de madera, un escritorio pequeño, sillas secretariales y sillas plásticas, donde atiende a los clientes, pues además de generar ingresos a través de la venta de mercancía variada,  también se dedica a vender minutos a celulares, actividad en la que es apoyada por  su hija, quien  vive en el primer piso  con su cónyuge, que se desempeña como vigilante independiente.
Nancy compra de contado y vende a crédito y siempre respondiendo a pedidos que le hacen los clientes, que ha venido fidelizando desde hace un poco menos de tres años; en la actualidad planea comprar con su primer credikiva, colonia, cremas, splash, tintes, talcos, pestañina, delineadores, ropa interior y medicinas naturales que presentan descuentos, para ganar un poco más de dinero mediante su compra en volúmenes y lograr que sus clientes también accedan a estas ofertas a un muy buen precio.
texts.en:
Nancy has been living in Soledad for three years in a two family home with her husband, who is an independent worker.  She sells merchandise via catalogue.  Her husband and her children help her support the home.  Nancy is associated with several catalogues through which she offers a variety of products like kitchen containers, cosmetics, underwear, natural remedies, etc.  Her business has a wooden display case, a small desk, secretarial chairs and plastic chairs where she tends to customers because, besides earning income selling assorted merchandise, she also sells minutes of cell phone air time, an activity her daughter, who lives on the first floor with her husband who is an independent Security Guard, helps her with.

Nancy pays cash for her merchandise and sells it on credit always responding to customer orders.  She has been establishing her base of regular customers for a little less than three years.  

She intends to use her first Kiva loan to buy cologne, creams, body wash, dyes, talc, eyelashes, eye liner, underwear and natural remedies that are on sale to earn a little more money buying them in volume so that her customers can also access these special offers at a very good price.

loans.use: to buy cologne, cream, body wash, dyes, talc, eyelashes, eye brow pencils, underwear and natural medicine that are on sale.

loans.name: Gerardo Ernesto

texts.es:
Gerardo, tiene treinta años de edad, vive con sus padres y una hermana, tiene un negocio de venta de productos comestibles como galletas, jugos, sodas, dulces y más.
El actualmente solicita un préstamo para aumentar su mercadería, comprando más de la antes mencionada, ya que son los productos que vende desde hace 6 años, con esta compra espera fortalecer y crecer en el negocio.
Su aspiración es crecer, mejorar las condiciones y calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Gerardo is 30 years old and lives with his parents and his sister.  He has a business selling food products such as biscuits, juice, soda, candy and more.
He is currently requesting a loan to increase his merchandise, buying more of the aforementioned, since they are the products he has been selling for 6 years. With this acquisition he hopes to strengthen and grow the business.  His aspiration is to grow, improve conditions and quality of life.

loans.use: To buy biscuits, juice, soda, candy, and more.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 43 years old and married with six children.

She earns a living by farming vegetables in the Philippines. Gloria is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Gloria has been farming vegetables for eight years and earns additional income from food vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is a hardworking entrepreneur who has an eatery business in the Philippines.  She has been in this business for 5 years.  She also earns additional income from raising pigs and selling dried fish.  

Joy is borrowing PHP 29500 through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients for her eatery business.   She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: buy ingredients for her eatery business

loans.name: Elba Yadira

texts.es: Elba Yadira de 49 años,  ella tiene su negocio que es la venta de mercadería en general. Esta actividad la realiza desde hace 8 años, pues además es maestra de primaria, pero como su  salario no puede mantener a su familia, decide empezar con esta actividad. Elba solicita este crédito para la compra de sabanas, cremas, ropa en general, calzado, ropa interior y otros productos. Esto le permitirá seguir brindando un buen servicio a su clientela, con los ingresos que obtenga podrá cubrir su crédito y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Elba Yadira is 49 years old and has a business selling general merchandise.  She has been in this business for eight years.  She also works as an elementary school teacher but her salary from that job is not enough to support her family with.  For this reason, she decided to start working in this business.

Elba is requesting this loan to buy sheets, creams, clothes, footwear, underwear and other products.  This will allow her to continue providing a good service to her customers.  She will use the income that she makes to repay her loan and improve her family's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy sheets, creams, clothes, footwear, underwear and other products

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a mother of 6 children, between 21 and 29 years old, with the last doing his post-secondary education. Esther's farm produces tea, milk, maize, beans, and bananas. She has employed one farmhand.

Esther has requested a loan of 47,100 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says the income will be used to see her last-born through his education. She is focusing on purchasing a plot of land to increase her farming income.

Esther is grateful to Juhudi for its loan intervention, but says unpredictable weather conditions, like hailstorms, are a constant threat to farmers.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Ma Dolores

texts.es: Doña Maria Dolores tiene 45 años de edad, tiene 2 hijos y es madre soltera, vive en casa de familiares y ella se dedica a criar borregos para poderlos vender cuando esten grandecitos, en su negocio que tiene lleva poco mas de 3 años  y nos dice que lo dificil es evitar que se enfermen, los borregos son animales muy especiales al igual que los puercos entonces hay que evitar tenerlos en malas condiciones, y pagar tambien veterinarios para que se puedan recuperar en caso de que se lleguena a enfermar, doña Maria quiere el prestamo para comprar un borrego y se pueda juntar con los demas que tiene en su corral, tambien nesecita algo de alimento para sus animales, ella desea poder tener muchos borregos y puercos porque de esa manera podra tener mejores ganancias y tambien para sus hijos seria un buende beneficio ya que estan estudiando. Uno de sus mayores sueños es tener su propia casa, aunque sea una pequeña pero quiere su propia casa.
texts.en: Maria Dolores, 45, is a single mother of 2 children and she lives in a house with relatives.  For more than 3 years she has been raising sheep to sell, and she tells us that it is difficult to avoid their getting sick.  Sheep are very special animals, like pigs, and it’s necessary to prevent them from being in bad condition and to pay veterinarians so that they can recuperate if they get sick.  Maria wants the loan to buy a sheep that she can put in the corral with the others.  She also needs animal feed.  She would like to have many sheep and pigs because this will give her better earnings and will also be a good benefit for her children since they are in school.  One of her biggest dreams is to have her own house, albeit small, but her own.

loans.use: to raise sheep to sell

loans.name: Tamaraneh Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Tamaraneh” group. They are small scale businesspeople based in Kenema, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are requesting for a loan of 800,000.00 SLL for each from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more profit consequently improving their living conditions. 

The leader of this group is Mohamed. Thirty-four-year-old Mohamed was born in Freetown. He is married to a student, and the couple has one child who is attending primary school. Mohamed sells used-clothes, and has been doing this business for many years now. With the help of this loan, he is going to buy a bale of business-clothes to add to his current stock.

loans.use: to buy a bale of business clothes to add to his current stock.

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
La  socia pertenece al banco comunal “CUSCO” el banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito D. Huanchac, en la Provincia D. Cusco y Departamento D. Cusco.

La  socia Marina; tiene 59 años D. edad,  la socia es viudo; la socia tiene 1 hijo D.  17 años D. edad; La socia tiene en su propia casa un pequeño negocio la socia ha puesto una pensión familiar, ella prepara diferentes potajes y los venD. a la hora del almuerzo, la socia prepara menús , este menú trae una sopa casera, un segundo que es el plato D. fondo, y una fruta o postre, mas el refresco, la socia piD. 2.50 soles por cada menú que ella venD., en las tardes ella prepara extras que son platos con presas muy grandes, bien servidos y cobra 5.00 nuevos soles; la socia también venD. cervezas chics a los clientes por las tardes y D. este modo ella tiene mayores ingresos, la socia solicita el préstamo en esta  ocasión el crédito para invertir en la compra D. insumos como arroz, aceite, papas, fideos y otros productos que le permitan ahorrar, también desea invertir en la compra D. cervezas para su venta, la socia solicita el préstamo para comprar insumos para la preparación D. los diferentes potajes y cervezas.

La  socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir D. manera disciplinada con los pagos D. las cuotas.
texts.en:
Marina belongs to CUSCO community bank which is located in Huanchac district, in Cusco province and department.  She is 59 years old, widowed, and has a 17-year-old son.

Marina has a small business in her home.  She has set up a small family restaurant where she prepares soups to sell at lunchtime.  She prepares set meals which incluD. a home-maD. soup, a main course, fruit or dessert, and a drink.  She asks 2.50 soles for each meal that she sells.  In the afternoon, she prepares larger meals which are well served.  For these she charges 5.00 soles.  In addition, Marina sells beer to her afternoon customers which makes her more income.  She is requesting a loan on this occasion to invest in buying supplies such as rice, oil, potatoes, noodles and other products which will allow her to save.  She would also like to invest in buying beer to sell.  She is requesting this loan to buy supplies for making her soups and also to buy beer.

Marina is grateful for the support that she will receive and, for her part, she pledges to make her loan repayments in a disciplined manner.

loans.use: to buy supplies for making different soups and to buy beer

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
This is Nenita, 56, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Felix, an overseas contract worker, and mother to their children. She, together with her children, manages the household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Nenita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store selling groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippine pesos (PHP) worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by buying her stock at wholesale prices and selling by the unit. She also cooks and sells viand, as well as selling school supplies. Her store is adjacent to her house and regular customers include her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 600 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue her business operations, she is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Nenita hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of having a canteen. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups, composed of 15 to 30 community partners, that meet on a weekly basis. They gather to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed for her business.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas is a 43-year-old married woman with 4 children. Her oldest child is 24 years old. Dorcas and her husband both work as farmers. They cultivate the land where they grow rice crops. Dorcas has been in the rice farming business for 26 years.

Dorcas has requested this loan to purchase fertilizers, herbicides and other farm inputs. Dorcas hopes for their business to grow. She also hopes for her children to finish their schooling and be successful.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, herbicides, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Thorng

texts.en:
Mrs. Thorng is a hard-working and hopeful woman. She works as a rice cultivator with her husband on the same farmland. Mrs. Thorng has been involved in agriculture and farming rice since 1990; she has learned this skill well from her parents. Besides helping Mrs.Thorng do the farming, her husband takes some time at home to raise poultry such as chickens and ducks, which are bred for eggs and meat for future sale. Together, this couple can earn around $6USD per day to cover the family’s needs. 

Mrs. Thorng has four children. Two of them work in garment factories. In order to make more income for the family, Mrs. Thorng has created a business for her daughter wholesaling and retailing clothes at a market in Phnom Penh. This business is running very well. Now Mrs. Thorng would like to request some funds from Kiva and HKL to buy additional clothes for selling, and with the remainder, she wants to use it to buy some zinc for re-covering their present house. 

Mrs. Thorng hopes that she will be able to secure her family from poverty.

loans.use: to buy additional clothes to sell

loans.name: Rodolita

texts.en:
Rodolita is 25 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Rodolita has a shop that sells "longganisa" or home-made sausage. She has had this business for 4 years. She requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy raw ingredients needed for making "longganisa".

Rodolita has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Rodolita hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed for making "longganisa" (sausage).

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly is married and has adult children and two others who still attend school.  She lives in Malindi, a coastal town in Kenya, popular with italian tourists.  She joined Milango eight months ago after being invited by a friend. 

Nelly is requesting a loan for 60,000 KES, which she will use to purchase more foodstuffs for her hotel. With this loan, Nelly will be able to pay her children's school fees.  With the rising need for transport in most upcoming centers in her area, Nelly would like to purchase motorcycles to serve her neighbors in the future.

loans.use: to purchase flour, sugar, and milk.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is 21 years old and lives in the town of Zanna in the Kampala West region of Uganda. For the past year, Monica has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells cosmetics. 

To help expand her business, Monica has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cosmetic  body lotions and will help Monica to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself. Monica hopes that in the future she will be able to become a doctor. 

Monica is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Monica's future prospects by helping her to improve her capital.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetic body lotions.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
To all appearances, the prospects of a lucrative spare-parts business in a far-off district like Ibanda seem minimal. It takes lots of enterprise, conviction, and credible ideas outside of the conventional box. This reality dawned on Benard a decade ago as he set forth in the aforementioned trade. A steady and satisfactory trajectory has been formidable to sustain and consolidate, but, nevertheless, Benard has made inroads. His kind of business would do really well in a metropolis like Kampala or Jinja, but Benard is undeterred.

He has been able to get into the good graces of those he has served, and, as such, has carved out his own niche. His clientele base is not so big if parallels are drawn with other entrepreneurs engaged in the same trade in places like Mbarara--fast becoming Western Uganda's commercial city. That, however, does not unnerve him. He is upbeat about the future prospects of his business, and he believes this Kiva loan will come in handy in his drive to open new horizons for his trade.

Benard, a lusty widower with four children, says he began his business with income from his crude alcohol sales business. Thus far, his business's sales returns total 500,000 Ugandan shillings. Benard also ekes out supplementary income from a modest food sales business. He says he will use this Kiva loan to purchase more spare parts to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more spare parts to resell

loans.name: Pamoja Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Pamoja Group in Western Kenya! Ruth is the facilitator of the group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Ruth is a mother of two children. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Ruth had a good maize yield harvesting 18 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, she was only able to harvest 9 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

 With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Ruth and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Ruth will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

 In 2012, the members of Pamoja group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize. They are pictured above with their Field Officer on the far left

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Felicetas

texts.en:
Felicetas is 65 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 11 children. 

Felicetas has run a food shop, or sari-sari store, for 50 years. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages to sell. Felicetas has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages to sell.

loans.name: Ola

texts.en:
Ola is a 34-year-old divorced woman from Madaba, Jordan.

Ola is requesting a loan of 500 JD to purchase clothing for trading purposes.

Ola is looking to open a shop for her business so that she can better display her products.

Due to cultural issues, the man in the photo is Ola's brother.

loans.use: to purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a 31-year-old single man. He describes himself as ambitious. He operates a motorcycle, providing motorcycle transportation. He has been involved in this business for 6 years. His business is located in a competitive area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the rainy season, as roads are impassible. He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to purchase motorcycle spare parts. Joseph's business goal is to own at least five motorcycles within 5 years.

loans.use: To buy motorcycle spare parts.

loans.name: Almira

texts.en:
Almira is 39 years old and married with two children who both attend school.  She is a very hard working entrepreneur.  Almira has a clothing retail business in the Philippines.  She has been in this business for four years.  

Almira requested a 23,000 PHP loan through Kiva partner Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy items like blouses, t-shirts, cosmetics and other personal products to sell.  In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy blouses, t-shirts, cosmetics and other personal products to sell.

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina(25) is a famer and fisherman at a floating village on Tonlesap River. She lives with her husband and they have one child Rath(6) who has just started to  attend school. They do fishing all seasons and farm during the dry season. They don’t have  enough electricity now. They want to buy solar system to be able to use electricity and save money on energy cost.

loans.use: to buy a solar home system

location.town: Kampong Ou Village, Khonrorng Commune, Boribo Dist

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: TERESITA, 47 YEAR OLD, MARRIED AND HAS 2 CHILDREN. SHE BORROWED A LOAN TO FOR ADDITIONAL PIG IN HER PIGGERY BUSINESS. THROUGH THIS BUSINESS SHE WAS ABLE TO PROVIDE THE NEEDS OF HER FAMILY AS A MOTHER. SHE WAS ABLE TO HELP HER HUSBAND, WHO IS A FARMER, WITH THEIR FINANCIAL NEEDS. AS A MOTHER SHE WANT TO GIVE HER CHILDREN AS WELL AS HER FAMILY A BETTER LIVES. HER DESIRE IS TO EXPAND HER BUSINESS AND ABLE TO SELL FOR MORE PIGS THAT WILL HELP THEM BIG.

loans.use: TO BUY FOR ADDITIONAL PIG IN HER BUSINESS

loans.name: Paola Patricia

texts.en:
Paola is a person that wants to come out on top through her own efforts. She is married and has a small child. They live in the city of Monclova, Coahuila, in a room of Paola\'s husband Antonio\'s parents. This is why about a year ago she started to sell jewellery with the goal of helping her husband with their expenses and to save money to be able to build a small house for their family.

She now needs a loan in the amount of $250, that will be used to purchase more merchandise and this way be able to more quickly build the house following and increase in her sales. She plans on repaying the full amount of the loan in a term of 3-6 months. Become a fundamental part of the realization of Paola\'s dream. Help her build a proper home. The decision is in yoru hands, you just need to make the move.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

Paola es una persona que quiere salir adelante por sus propios méritos, es casada y tiene un hijo pequeño. Ellos viven en la localidad de Monclova, Coahuila, en un cuarto de la casa de los padres de Antonio, esposo de Paola. Es por ello que hace poco más de un año ella comenzó a vender joyería con el objetivo de poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos y además poder juntar capital para construir una pequeña casita para su familia.

Ella ahora necesita de un crédito por una cantidad de $250 DLLS, mismos que utilizará para comprar más mercancía y así poder construir más rápido su casa ante el incremento de las ventas. Planea regresar el monto total del crédito en un plazo de 3-6 mese. Se parte fundamental de la realización del sueño de Paola, ayúdale a construir un hogar propio, la decisión esta en tus manos sólo hace falta que te decidas.

loans.use: PURCHASE MERCHANDISE

loans.name: Esther Manjoh

texts.en:
Born in 1972, Esther is a mother of five children. The death of her sister increased her parenting responsibility to nine children, and the often ill-health of her children is her motivation to become economically empowered. Esther is a fourth-time borrower. Her three previous loans provided her community with water-fu-fu (This is ground cassava prepared as thick porridge eaten with different types of soup. The favorite in this area is “water-fu-fu & erru”.) This gained her the name “Mami water-fu-fu”.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to maintain leadership in the supply of "water-fu-fu" in her quarter, stock in new items of "equsi" and cooking oil. Her long time goal is to own a restaurant and help others in need.

She plans to pay loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Producing water-fu-fu

loans.name: Uk

texts.en:
Mrs. Uk S., a 40-year-old mother of 6 children, lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She sells vegetables on a roadside of this village and typically makes around $5/day, while her husband is both a farmer and a construction worker. Uk S. has to get up in the early morning to pick the vegetables in her farm and then sell them to retailers. With this business activity, she barely makes sufficient money for her family's expenses, but she has an idea to increase a size of her income by giving chance to one of her children to be a tuk-tuk driver. To help this, S. is asking for $600 to purchase a tuk-tuk ( a passenger cart attached with motor-bike) for her son. 
For the coming year, S.'s husband plans to maximize crops in his farm, so that he will make additional income to supplement his household.

loans.use: To purchase a tuk tuk for her son to run a business.

loans.name: Angela, Ricarda /joc

texts.en:
Angela Maria R. and her sister, Ricarda, were born in the town of Nagua, about 80 miles north of Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic. They ran a beauty parlor there for several months before relocating to Santo Domingo with their families. Their shop has been in its new location for 8 months and is doing very well. Angela Maria has four children and Ricarda has one child (seen here in photo). They all live together in the same house with their mother, and the salon is located in an extension of the house. Even though the shop is small, they can work on at least two customers at the same time.

Angela and Ricarda have applied for a loan in part to buy a small power generator so that their shop can continue to operate during the eight to ten hours a day when the electricity is out in their neighborhood.

They are also interested in opening up a new business with their partner, Jocelyn B., to sell natural and herbal remedies produced by a company called Natura International. To make this possible, Angela and Ricarda have applied for loans of $350 each, and Jocelyn for a loan of $200, for a total of $900.

Sale of natural and herbal remedies is a recent development in this area, but the activity sounds very promising. Until this business has proved itself, however, securing loans will be difficult. But we believe the fact that these three women are working together to make it happen is a good sign that bodes well for repayment of the loan. Also, the beauty parlor is profitable and can help them withstand early losses from the newer herbal business. That's one reason why, for purposes of this loan, we are considering these women as part of one team.

loans.use: Emergency power plant and sales of  herbal medicine.

loans.name: Sanaa

texts.en:
Sanaa, 39 years old, is the owner of a small tailoring business in the area of Sid Al Bauchrieh in Beirut. Sanaa has been a client of Al Majmoua for the past 3 years. Before knowing Al Majmoua, Sanaa was employed in a clothing factory, being paid $1 to $2 per piece of clothing she was tailoring. With the first loan from Al Majmoua, she bought her own sewing machine - the one shown in the picture - quit the factory and opened her own business.
Since then, she has tripled her monthly income and is currently the main source of income for her family (her retired parents have no income).  
Sanaa needs a loan of $1,000 to buy a large stock of fabrics and accessories for her business.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics and accessories to tailor new pieces of clothing

loans.name: Lum

texts.en: Lum R. is a 67-year-old widow who is her family's main breadwinner. She needs to increase her income because she is responsible for the care of both her children and her grandchildren. Lum has applied for a loan that will allow her to grow yams, corn, beans and cocoyams on her family's plot. She will use the income made possible by this loan to buy medicines she needs, and pay school fees for her children and her grand children.

loans.use: Buy seeds to grow yams, corn, beans, cocoyams; pay for transport to market

loans.name: Carmelina Esabelina

texts.es:
Carmelina belongs to the Commmunity Bank of Señor D. Cautivo II. She works selling articles of clothing (trousers, jackets, blouses etc.): her sales pitch is located in a gallery on Luzuriaga Avenue in Huaraz Province, Ancash department.

With this loan of 1300 soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy a dozen trousers, a dozen jackets for the Christmas festivities and two dozen blouses.

Carmelina is 36 years old, and married with two children. Her income from the clothing sales allows her to pay the rent, educate her children and help her husband with the other household expenses.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

L. señora Carmelina pertenece al Banco Comunal Señor D. Cautivo II, se dedica a L. venta D. prendas D. vestir (pantalones, casacas, camisas y otros), su puesto D. venta esta ubicado en una Galería D. L. Avenida Luzuriaga D. L. provincia D. Huaraz, departamento D. Ancash.

Con este préstamo D. S/ 1,300.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará 1 docena D. pantalones, 1 docena D. casacas para las fiestas naviD.ñas y 2 docenas D. camisas.

ElL. tiene 36 años D. edad, está casada y tiene 2 hijos. Sus ingresos le permite pagar el alquiler D. su casa, educar a sus hijos y apoyar a su esposo en los otros gastos D. hogar.

loans.use: Purchase clothing items wholesale

loans.name: Eugenia's Group

texts.en:
Ana Maria and Eugenia have been members of the community bank Sarita for two and eleven years respectively.

Ana Maria is 23 years old. She lives with her partner and is expecting her first child. She has been selling vegetables in the Nery Garcia market of Ayacucho for one year; she learned this business from her mother. Ana Maria would like to change her business to sell groceries and condiments. Eugenia has a grocery store in the center of Ayacucho and has been selling groceries since she was very young.

In their community bank they have learned to save and to be responsible and punctual. They have also learned valuable social skills such as how to educate their children, how to respect themselves, and how to support other bank associates.

Eugenia and Ana Maria each need loans of 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying onions, squash, cilantro, parsley, tomato, beans, sugar, rice, and milk.

The community bank emphasizes the importance of saving and each associate has an interest-earning account. Ana Maria and Eugenia plan to use their savings to increase the capital available for their business, to buy a house, and to pay for medical care if a family member gets sick. Eugenia and Ana Maria dream of owning a home, giving their children a good education, having good health, and that no one in their family will lack anything they need.

loans.use: Eugenia and Ana Maria each need loans of 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying onions, squash, cilantro, parsley, tomato, beans, sugar, rice, and milk.

loans.name: Suos

texts.en: Mrs. Suos S., 34, is married with three school-aged children, and works selling a variety of grocery products to the people in her area, making on average $7 each day in revenue. Her husband works driving a motor-taxi, and his passenger base is near a market. Mrs. Suos S. hopes to use this loan to purchase more grocery products to meet her clients’ needs and to buy pigs to breed for an additional profit.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to meet her clients’ needs and to buy pigs to breed for an additional profit.

loans.name: Paula

texts.es:
Mrs. Paula belongs to the communal bank “Las Caribenas” located on block 9 of Jr. Athahualpa, in the district of Calleria, in the department of Ucayali. She is 35 years old and a mother of 2 boys. Her husband also works as a merchant.

Presently Paula owns a small hardware store. She wakes up very early so she can take care of her children, her husband and complete all of her household chores. When she leaves her house in the afternoons she sells her products to her customers.

She then dedicates all of her time and energy to her business. In the afternoons she also goes to collect money from customers that bought on credit. With this loan of 1800 Soles, which she will pay in 4 months, she will buy nails, paint, tar, tubes, and metal rods.

She feels very happy with her business. When she began her business she didn’t image that this would give her so much personal satisfaction.

Translated from Spanish by Gabe of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteer

La señora Paula pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Caribeñas, ubicado en el Jr. Atahualpa Cdra. 9, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 35 años es madre de 2 hijos, su esposo es comerciante.

En la actualidad cuenta con una ferretería, se levanta muy temprano para atender a sus hijos y esposo, luego se dedica a la atención de su negocio también va a cobrar sus créditos que deja a sus clientes.

Con este préstamo recibido de S/. 1,800, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprara clavos, pintura, brea, tubos, fierros, etc.

Paula se siente muy contenta, cuando inicio su negocio no imagino que le iba a dar tantas satisfacciones y logros personales.

loans.use: purchasing products

loans.name: Akyea

texts.en:
Akyea J. is a wholesale dealer in electrical and general goods. He is married but has no child. Demand for his goods is increasing by the day. But his capital is not sufficient to meet the demand of his customers.

He is asking for $525 as additional capital to enable him to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: As additional capital to enable him to buy more goods for sale

loans.name: Jameratu

texts.en:
Jameratu A. is thirty nine years old. She is a wife and mother of two children, who are currently in school. She works very hard because she thinks duty demands that she provide brighter opportunities for her children. She is determined to send at least one of her children to medical school. That is her motivation. Mary Prah, her mother, helps her because Jameratu had to go to the hospital for treatment for a minor illness (Mary is in the picture).

Jameratu owns and operates a grocery shop in one of the busy local markets. She sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, canned foods, peanuts, and evaporated milk. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of evaporated milk and vegetable oil, among other items. This will increase her stock.

Jameratu belongs to the community group called Shepherd Trust Group. In this group, members use social collateral to guarantee the loans for one another. They use positive peer pressure to encourage each other to repay the loans.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice and sugar, cartons of evaporated milk, and vegetable oil.

loans.name: Samut

texts.en:
Mrs. Samut P., age 43, and her husband, Mr. Sal Sum, age 51, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers north of Phnom Penh, were married in 1979 and have 6 children: 3 sons and 3 daughters. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home. Of the other 3 children, 1 of them is a construction worker and the other 2 are in a local school.

Mrs. Samut and her husband have been farming for 40 years. They grow rice and many kinds of vegetables in the village. Besides the farming business, Mr. Sal is also a carpenter as well. Now Mrs. Samut is requesting a loan of US$600 to rent more land for farming and some for repairing her house.

loans.use: To rent a field for farming and repairing her house

loans.name: Dina Soledad

texts.es:
Dina Soledad is 26 years old and she studied until third grade of primary school. She speaks Spanish and is Aymara. She's single and she rents a house in the Jr Tarapaca district, in the province of Yunguyo.

Four years ago she opened a grocery store which was her mother's idea. She joined the group Banco Comunal Estrellita del Sur and got an initial loan of $300 soles with which she bought rice, noodles, soap, sugar and sweets.

She now rents out a cement mixer.

With the loan of $600 soles which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy a mixer.

Dina is very grateful for the credits as they have helped her to support herself. Her vision for the future is to have a huge grocery store, buy her own house with which to support her parents.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Dina soledad tiene 26 años de edad, estudio hasta tercer año de primaria, habla el idioma castellano y aymará, es soltera, la casa donde vive es alquilada y esta ubicada en el Jr. Tarapacá Distrito, Provincia de Yunguyo. Ella nos cuenta que hace 4 años atrás, aperturó una tienda de abarrotes la cual fue idea de su mama; integrando al Banco Comunal Estrellita del Sur ,adquiriendo un préstamo inicial de S/. 300.00 soles con lo que compro arroz, fideos, jabón, Azúcar, gaseosas. Actualmente se dedica ala actividad de alquiler de maquina mezcladora de cemento. Con este préstamo de S/.600.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará una máquina mezcladora. Dina esta muy agradecida por los créditos, además aprendió ha ser solidaria. Su visión futura es tener una gran tienda de abarrotes ,comprar su casa propia para lo cual cuenta con el apoyo de sus padres .

loans.use: To buy a cement mixer/Compra de máquina mezcladora.

loans.name: Santos Nelida

texts.es:
Santos is 78 years old and widowed. She completed primary school, but left because she had a difficult illness and her parents couldn’t afford treatment for her. Santos has eight children who all have found work.

To support herself financially, at a young age Santos started selling grocery items out of her home in San Pedro de Lloc District, Pacasmayo Province in La Libertad state. Her daughter-in-law referred her to the San Pedrito Community Bank, where she was accepted. Santos has been with Manuela Ramos for four years. She used her first loan of 300 soles [about US $100] to purchase grocery items such as rice and oil. With a loan of 1,000 soles [about US $ 350], which will be paid back in six months, Santos plans to purchase toilet paper, oil, rice, soft drinks, small soaps, gum, sewing supplies, etc. Santos’s goal is to buy her house and support her grandson financially so he can get a professional job.

Translated from Spanish by Todd M. Anderson

La señora Santos Nelida, tiene 78 años, es viuda, estudió primaria completa, no continuó estudiando porque tuvo una enfermedad delicada y sus padres no tenían el dinero suficiente para poder ayudarla, tiene 8 hijos, se encuentran trabajando.

Para ayudarse económicamente empezó desde joven en su negocio de abarrotes, en su casa en el Distrito de San Pedro de Lloc en la Provincia de Pacasmayo en el Departamento de La Libertad. Su nuera la recomendó en el Banco Comunal “SAN PEDRITO”, ahí mismo la aceptaron. Tiene cuatro años trabajando con Manuela Ramos, y con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 invirtió en compra de abarrotes como arroz y aceite. Con el crédito de S/. 1000.00 que cancelará en un plazo de 06 meses tiene pensado comprar papel higiénico, aceite, arroz, gaseosas, jaboncillo, chicles, mercería, etc. La socia tiene como meta comprar su casa y ayudar económicamente a su nieto para que sea profesional.

loans.use: Purchase of various products (grocery items)

location.town: San Pedro de Lloc - La Libertad

loans.name: Dania

texts.en:
Dania is a 28-year-old woman who lives in Hasbaya, Southern Lebanon.
Dania sells cosmetic creams and makeup to local women. Dania is part of a solidarity group called "Gardenia," and has asked for a loan of $300 to purchase new cosmetics for her burgeoning retail business.

loans.use: To help expand her makeup stock

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es:
La señora Felicitas tiene 85 años de edad pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Rumbo Al éxito II”, después de la muerte de su esposo ella ha buscado que sus hijos se unan y los cinco que aún viven puedan vivir con la herencia que su esposo les dejó afirma que su vida siempre ha estado llena de alegrías, aun cuando se hizo cargo de su casa, siempre; en la actualidad vive con sus dos hijas y cinco nietos que le ayudan a seguir viviendo.
Sin embargo lucha infranqueablemente para ayudar en casa, ella al igual que su hija trae ropas por mayor de la ciudad de lima y los vende entre clientes ya conocidos.

Con este préstamo de 300 soles, que pagará en cuatro cuotas, ella ayudará a su hija para que arregle la fachada de su casa que se encuentra en una zona comercial en la ciudad de Huaraz y así la puedan alquilar y generarse otros ingresos.
texts.en:
Felicitas is 85 years old and belongs to the Communal Bank "Mujeres Rumbo Al éxito II." After the death of her husband she looked for her chidren to stay together and the five of them still can live on the inheritance that her husband left them. She says that her life has always been full of joy, even when she had to manage her home herself; today she lives with her 2 daughters and 5 grandchildren that help her continue living. Nevertheless she insurmountably fights to help around the house. She, like her daughter, brings clothing at wholesale from Lima and sells it to customers. With this loan for 300 soles, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will help her daughter fix the front wall of her home which is located in a commercial zone of Huaraz city and in this way she will be able to rent it and generate additional income.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Maintain the front wall of her home

loans.name: Sakhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sakhorn S., 56, and her husband, Mr. Thai Hong, 61, married in 1970. They have nine children, six sons and three daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside of the family home. The other children are either garment factory workers or construction workers. The youngest studies at the local school. The family lives along National Road Number Six about twenty Kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sakhorn and her husband have been farming for thirty years. They grow rice, hemp and lotuses on their farmland. They sell their yield to the middleman in the village. Sakhorn is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase rice seeds, fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.use: To purchase rice seeds, fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Salif

texts.fr:
C’est dans le quartier Heremakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni(troisième région administrative du Mali)que Monsieur Salif D.,  âgé de 48 ans vit avec ses  7 enfants et son épouse dans une famille nucléaire.
Après plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus sans succès, il opte d’évoluer dans le secteur de la prestation de services en l’occurrance le collage de pneus et la soudure(electrique et au chalumeau). Il a fait  un long apprentissage auprès de son oncle durant lequel il capitalisa une somme de connaissances. Avec une expérience de 10 ans Monsieur Salif D. maîtrise son activité et est très apprécié à Bougouni. Son atelier est situé sur l’artère principale  reliant Bougouni à  la préfecture de Yanfolila( frontière Guinnéenne de Conakry).
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante décide collaborer avec le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à sa premier prêt. Individuel.
Il compte acheter, 10 douzaines de baguettes, 2 pneus et 1 pompe à air à Bamako(capitale de la république du Mali) ou quelques fois sur place à Bougouni auprès des quincailliers. Sa clientèle est composée surtout de routiers et de quelques habitants de la ville.
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour renforcer son entreprise.
texts.en:
The Heremakono Nord neighborhood of Bougouni (third administrative region of Mali) is where Mr. Salif D. lives. He is 48 years old and lives with his wife and seven children in a nuclear family. After several unsuccessful money-making business activities, he decided to opt specifically for providing tire fixing and welding (electric and blowtorch) services. He served a long apprenticeship with his uncle, during which he accumulated a wealth of knowledge. With 10 years’ experience, Mr. D. has mastered his craft and is highly thought of in Bougouni. His workshop is located on the main road joining Bougouni to the Yanfolila prefecture (the border with Conakry in Guinea). In order to satisfy his ever-increasing clientele he decided to get involved with the credit program run by the microfinance organization, Soro Yiriwaso – a Kiva partner. This is his first personal loan. He intends to buy 10 dozen rods, two tires and an air pump in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) or even from the ironmongers in Bougouni itself. His clientele includes mainly truck drivers and some town residents. He hopes to make a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA ($150) that he will use for improvements to his business.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials for fixing tires and for welding

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en: Mrs. Saroeun S. is a farmer in Boeung Nay village in Kampong Cham province. She owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice. She wants to expand her plantation because she doesn't earn enough income to provide a better life for her family. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy another piece of land to cultivate rice on. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living conditions with this loan. Mrs. Saroeun S. is a widow with two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school.

loans.use: to add to her savings to buy another piece of land to cultivate rice on

loans.name: Badegna : La Parenté Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badegna de l’association Sabaly de kimparana est composé de 5 femmes mariées, elles vivent dans de grandes familles avec une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans  et ont chacune 4 enfants. Ce groupe de femmes s’est spécialisé dans la vente de légumes et de condiments alimentaires.
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités les clientes ont décidé d’intégrer depuis maintenant trois ans le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont  à leur cinquième prêt de groupe (prêt solidaire).Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursement sans difficulté.
Ce prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des légumes frais (bananes Plantain, patate douce, igname  et autres) à Sikasso, koury et Bobo  qui seront revendus au fur et à mesure car ne peuvent être stockés pour longtemps. Elles revendent au marché de kimparana,  à la maison, au carrefour et dans les marchés voisins  comme San, Koury et Tominia.
Elles prétendent avoir un bénéfice de 120 000 F CFA avec ce prêt. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt  et faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The "Badegna" group of the Sabaly association of Kimparana is made up of five married women. They live in large families, average 41 years of age and each have four children. This group of women specializes in selling vegetables and condiments. To increase the size of their businesses, these clients decided three years ago to join the loans program of Soro Yiriwaso with which they are now on their fifth group loan. All previous loans were fully repaid. This loan will allow them to buy fresh vegetables such as plantains, sweet potatos, yams among others in Sikasso, Koury and Bobo to retail over time as they do not keep long. They sell at the Kimparana market, at home, at crossroads, and in neighbouring marketplaces such as San, Koury and Tominia. They believe they will make a profit of 120,000 FCFA thanks to this loan. This profit will be used to repay the loan interest and to contribute to the household expenses.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables and condiments.

loans.name: Pablo Antonio

texts.es:
Pablo G. es un caballero originario del municipio de El Viejo el cual se dedica a su actividad de agricultura llevado a cabo en su comunidad por medio de la siembra de frijoles. También se dedica arduamente a la construcción de casas, teniendo estas dos actividades donde se desarrolla para llevar el sustento a su humilde familia compuesta por su esposa y tres hijos.

Hoy en día espera en Ceprodel para obtener el crédito para la compra de los insumos para la siembra de los frijoles y para esto continua esforzándose en su construcción esperando tranquilamente en el apoyo que solamente Ceprodel puede brindarle.
texts.en:
Pablo G. is originally from the municipality of El Viejo, where he still makes a living in his community's agriculture by harvesting beans. He also works arduously building homes. He has these two activities to carry out so he can provide for his family, which consists of his wife and three children. Currently, he comes to Kiva partner Ceprodel in request of a loan so he can purchase the raw materials to plant his bean crops and also continue working hard in construction. He calmly waits for the support that only Kiva and Ceprodel can provide.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in raw materials for harvesting beans and building homes

loans.name: Ato

texts.en: Ato A., 31, is married and has three children. She has one year of experience in planting, harvesting, and  selling bananas and taro. She sells to the Fugalei market and to the general public three days a week. This is her first loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (about $104 USD). SPBD loans are Ato’s only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with traditional banks. She wants to improve her business so that she can raise her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy pesticides, chemicals, and planting equipment

loans.name: Maud

texts.en:
Maud O. is 30 years old. She is single and lives independently in a rented apartment in Nkawkaw, in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Nkawkaw is a busy commercial town in the region. She works hard to help herself.

She is a hair dresser by profession. Maud has graduated from apprenticeship and currently runs her owns shop. She says most of the women in her neighborhood call on her for her services, probably due to her ingenuity. She wants a loan to procure things such as lotions, creams, pomades, shampoo, etc. to improve upon her services to her cherished clients.

Maud has been in business for three years. It is her desire to be financially sound before she enters into marriage.

loans.use: Buy toiletries to support her business.

loans.name: Aoua

texts.fr:
Aoua B. a 37 ans, mère de six  enfants (3 garçons  3 filles) et vit dans un foyer monogame avec son époux et ses enfants à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, elle s’est très vite initiée aux activités de petit commerce telle que l’achat et la vente d’ oignon, de pomme de terre, de patate,  de mangue, d’orange, etc. Elle mène son activité au nouveau marché de Médine Sikasso depuis maintenant trois ans et est très sollicitée.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant trois ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son premier prêt individuel.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 20 sacs d’oignon de qualités différentes, 10 sacs de pomme de terre et 20 sacs de patate. Elle fait ses achats  en gros sur place auprès des agriculteurs venant à la foire avant de les revendre en détail au comptant  et à crédit .
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Aoua B., 37, is the mother of six children (three boys and three girls) and lives in a monogamous household with her husband and her children in Hamdallaye, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Not having had the good fortune to go to school, she got into petty trading early on, selling onions, potatoes, yams, mangoes, and oranges, etc. She has had her sales point in the new market of Médine Sikasso for three years now and is much in demand.

Wishing to satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso 3 years ago. After 4 solidarity loans (group loans) with an association of women from her neighborhood, she is now on her first individual loan.

She expects to use this loan to buy 20 sacks of varying grades of onions, 10 sacks of potatoes, and 20 sacks of yams. She buys her products wholesale right where she lives, from the farmers who come to the weekly markets, before re-selling them retail, for cash or credit.

She expects to use this loan to make a monthly profit of 50,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to increase her working capital, contribute to family expenses and pay the interest on her loan, investing any remainder back into her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of onions and yams for re-sale

loans.name: Al

texts.en:
Mr. P. is a resident of Poblacion Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental, 39 years old, a businessman and blessed with 2 children. He is married to Fritzie P., who is also a businesswoman.

Mr. P. decided to become a member just for insurance purposes in our individual program on April 14, 2007. Later on, in May 2008, he requested a loan for his business as additional capital and paid without reaching its term. They have a grocery store and cell phone selling in some nearby municipalities.

Lately, he decided to request a loan again, his 2nd, amounting to 20,000 pesos. Their children are in grade school and High School level. As for his previous loan, he repaid on time, having no default; contribution and obligations were responded accordingly. Business status is so good, they also are working with rice vending.

Mr. P. wants in the future to own his own stocks. He said he wants his children to finish their studies just like other parents aim for their children to become professionals someday.

loans.use: purchase of grocery items such as noodles, rice, soft drinks, and household materials

loans.name: Saibou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Saibou Samaké est un homme  de 37 ans et père de 3 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans une famille monogame dans le  quartier Dougounina de la ville de  Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali)
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, très vite il commença les activités génératrices de revenus.
Avant de mener l’activité d’achat et de vente des appareils électroniques qu’il a appris auprès d’un frère, Monsieur Saibou était cultivateur au village pendant 10 ans.
Avec une expérience de 3 ans,  Saibou Samaké maîtrise bien son activité commerciale et est très réputé de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il décida de rejoindre  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel pour acheter des appareils électroniques (lampes, torches, radios...).
Il s’approvisionne auprès des grossistes à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali)  et effectue sa vente sur place à Bougouni à une clientèle  composée de la population locale et des forains venant des villages environnants.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Saibou Samaké compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et subvenir aux dépenses de la famille.
Dans les années à venir il envisage agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Saibou Samaké, age 37, is the father of three children and lives with his wife and children in a monogamous family in the Dougounina district of the city of Bougouni (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having attended school, he soon began working to earn a living. Before running a business buying and selling electronics that he learned from his brother, he was a village farmer for ten years. With three years of experience, he has a good command of his commercial business and is well-known by his customers, who are growing in number. In his search for supplemental financial resources, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso and is on his first individual loan for buying electronics (lamps, flashlights, radios...) Supplies are gotten from wholesalers in Bamako (capital of Mali), and sales are made locally in Bougouni to customers composed of local people and fair vendors from surrounding villages. With this loan, he intends to realize a monthly profit of 30,000 francs CFA that will be used to make loan interest payments and to provide for his family. In the years to come, he envisions expanding his shop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy electronic goods

loans.name: Đặng's Group

texts.en:
"Đặng Thị T. H. (20203050056) is a 31-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Đặng is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Ô Cách 10 (10).


Đặng is married and has one infant child.  To make a living, Đặng works in someone else's business venture.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from manufacturing & selling to local businesses and community members.  Đặng has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 2.500.000 VND a month from these activities.


Đặng joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Đặng is requesting for the first time a loan from SEDA.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5.152.000 VND which will be used to purchase tools & other equipment to expand the business.  The loan will be the first loan taken out by her from SEDA.  Đặng plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nguyễn Thị T. (20203050057) is a 54-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  Trương Thị L. (20203050058) is a 22-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business.


3.  Trương Thị H. (20203050059) is a 24-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector operating a furniture making business.


4.  Trương Thị B. (20203050060) is a 34-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.


5.  Cao Thị Luyến (20203050061) is a 50 year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector operating a furniture making business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Đặng Thị T. H. (20203050056) là 31 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Đặng là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Ô Cách 10 (10).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các pH. thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ sản xuất & bán cho các doanh nghiệp và người dân trong cộng đồng địa pH..  Đặng thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Đặng kiếm được khoảng 2.500.000 VND.  Đặng đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Đặng đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ SEDA.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn Thị T. (20203050057) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Trương Thị L. (20203050058) là 22 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh sản xuất.


3.  Trương Thị H. (20203050059) là 24 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


4.  Trương Thị B. (20203050060) là 34 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


5.  Cao Thị Luyến (20203050061) là 50 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase tools & other equipment to expand the business

loans.name: Marie-Claire

texts.fr: F. Marie- Claire est née le 22/07/1959 à Takon dans la Commune de Sakété dans le Département de Plateau au Sud du Bénin. Marie-Claire est mariée à FATOKE Jacob ; mais elle est veuve depuis un an. Marie-Claire est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et maintenant à sa charge.  Marie-Claire vend les vêtements et chaussures à Agblangandan un quartier de la ville de Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Marie- Claire vend aussi des repas, précisément le riz. C'est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Marie- Claire fait ses provisions pour préparer le riz. Quant aux vêtements, c’est à Lomé, Capitale de TOGO pays frontalier au Bénin que Marie- Claire fait ses achats. Marie- Claire a déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits de ALIDé; crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu amener ses activités à un stade supérieur. Pour renforcer son fonds de roulement dans l'optique de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Marie- Claire sollicite un sixième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
F. Marie-Claire was born on July 22, 1959 in Takon in the community of Sakété, in Plateau county in southern Benin. She is married to FATOKE Jacob; but she has been a widow for a year. She is the mother of three children who are all in school and now in her care. Marie-Claire sells clothing and shoes in Agblangandan, a district in the city of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. She also sells meals, rice to be exact. Dantokpa, the grand international market of Benin, is where she finds her provisions for making rice dishes. As for clothing, it is in Lomé, the capital of Togo, a country bordering Benin, that she makes her purchases. Marie-Claire has already benefited from five loans with Alidé. She was able to use them to raise her business to a higher level. To boost her working capital with the aim of satisfying her customers more, she is requesting a sixth loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two 50-kg sacks of rice and seven dozen shoes, as well as clothing for children

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es:
La señora Elsa, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Sra. de Guadalupe”, Distrito de Bellavista, Provincia Bellavista, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 44 años y es madre de 03 hijos, todos ellos ya independientes.

Con la seguridad de tener una buena sazón para la preparación de diferentes tipos de comidas, por iniciativa propia con  su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 emprendió su negocio de venta de comida, ubicando su a las afueras de su casa, un ambiente muy bien acondicionado.

En la actualidad, pese al tiempo transcurrido continúa con el mismo negocio, contando con una clientela ya fidelizada que a diario acuden a su negocio de venta, donde ella los atiende con el carisma que le caracteriza. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, comprará insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos como sacos de arroz, azúcar; aceites en paquetes, pollos en javas y también  algunos utensilios  para implementar su negocio y dar una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Se siente aun con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando y seguir adelante y asegurarse una  vejez tranquila. Elsita, agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Elsa belongs to the Community Bank "Our Lady of Guadalupe," in the Bellavista District, Bellavista Province, San Martin Departmnet. She lives with her partner, is 44 years old, and is the mother of three children, all of whom are already independent. With the security of having a good seasoning for the preparation of different types of food, her own initiative with her first loan of S. 300 started her business selling food, located outside of her house, a well conditioned area. In actuality she has passed the time continuing with the same business, counting on an already loyal clientele who come to her business daily, where she takes care of them with the charisma which characterizes her. With this loan of S. 1,000 she will buy ingredients for the daily preparation of her foods like sacks of rice, sugar, oils in packets, chickens and also some utensils to implement in her business and give better attention to her clients. She feels like she has a lot of strength to continue working and continue forward and ensure herself a quiet old age. Elsita is thankful to the Manuela Ramos movement for contributing with the realization of her hopes and dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ingredients for the daily preparation of food

loans.name: Helena

texts.en:
Helena M. is married and has five dependents. She has received schooling through primary school.

Helena sells wheat, water, bread and soft drinks in Elmina, which she has done since 1999. Her husband is self-employed. Helena uses her income to pay for school fees and bills.

Helena will use the loan to buy more food supplies for resale to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save and educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more food supplies for resale

loans.name: Isabel Cristina

texts.en:
Isabel, 33, is a member of the Purple Christ communal bank. She has three children. The first two are 17 and 15 years old and go to school, but her last child is only 10 months old. Isabel studied cosmetics in school and started a job in that field after she finished her education. However, she quit that job because it did not pay very well, and with her savings she started a business selling parts and accessories for cell phones. She also started a small convenience store operating out of her house.

Since she has been with FINCA she says her life has been better, and she appreciates all of the loans she has been able to take out. Isabel now needs a loan of 1,600 soles to buy noodles, rice, oil, and beans which she wants to sell in her store. Her dream is to keep growing her business.

loans.use: To buy noodles, rice, oil, and beans which she wants to sell in her store

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou Tessara, a 26-year-old mother, is a pig grower. She has two children, the eldest being 6 years old, and both are studying in school.

Marilou dreams that someday she will have a larger piggery business where she can raise more pigs and earn the funds she needs to pay for her children’s education and daily costs at home.

Marilou started her business in 2004. Aside from pigs, she also sells banana crackers and earns Php 6,000 a month by being a seller.

Receiving a loan of Php 8,000 is truly worthwhile because Marilou plans to buy piglets and pig feed. She is very optimistic that her business will grow and wishes to earn a better income for her family.

Marilou said that she likes the services of CEVI because they give the lowest interest rate, which is 2% a month and is very affordable to repay.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en:
Chantal U. is 46 years old, is married with five children, and she takes care of eight dependents.

Chantal has been in the business of selling clothes for fiive years, working ten hours a day, but her monthly earnings are still low. For that reason, she is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through buying more clothes to sell.

By receiving this loan, Chantal hopes to earn more profit than before. Then, through that profit, she will be able to provide more food for her family and pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Jawad

texts.en:
Jawad is a 22-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon. He owns a barber shop and also sells beauty products. He requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is the first time that Jawad has requested a loan.

When Jawad first started his work, he didn’t face difficulties; his clients are his friends and neighbors. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan B. is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 from Kiva lenders. He wants this loan to buy house building materials like bags of cement, steel windows and boards. Hassan was born in Kamalo, about seven miles away from Makeni. He is thirty-six years old. He is married to businesswoman and they have five children. Two of his children are in secondary school and three are in primary school.

loans.use: Buy house building materials

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mr. Seng K., 51 years old, is pictured above with his wife. They reside in Pursat Province, Cambodia. This older couple earns a living by cultivating rice and raising pigs as well. They are also the good parents of eight children. Three of the children are married and live separately; the others are single, either employed or students.

Seng K. is taking out his first loan to purchase a boat that he will use for fishing activities. This loan will provide his family with extra income and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a boat that he will use for fishing activities

loans.name: Solange

texts.fr: D. Solange est née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une veuve et mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés, dont un est à sa charge. Solange vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule les charges de la famille. C'est depuis 24 ans que Solange réside à Agblangandan dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Solange n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Solange mène depuis 12 ans environs comme activité, la vente de poissons congelés à Abattoir dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. C'est au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Solange s'approvisionne. Solange est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Dans l'optique de renforcer son activité en complétant le stock de ses produits, et de mieux satisfaire la demande des clients, Solange sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Solange D. was born in 1973 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a widow and has three children in school, of whom one is in her care. Solange lives alone with her child and provides for her family by herself. For 24 years, Solange has lived in Agblangandan in the town of Sèmè-Podji, Benin. Solange never went to school. For about 12 years, Solange has run a business selling frozen fish at the abattoir in the town of Sèmè-Podji. It is in Nigeria, a country bordering Benin, that Solange gets her supplies. Solange is a longtime client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) who has repaid her loans properly. With the goal of strengthening her business by topping up her stock of products and better satisfying the demands of her customers, Solance is seeking a fifth loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 20 boxes of fish

loans.name: Juana Azurduy Group

texts.es: El Banco D. emprendimiento ingresa a su sexto ciclo, fue fundado el 25 D. Enero del 2008; la Sra.
